message_1: Suppose you have two propositions: P: "It is raining today" and Q: "The sky is cloudy." Use propositional logic to determine the truth value of the following proposition: "If it is raining today, then the sky is cloudy."
message_2:
To determine the truth value of the proposition "If it is raining today, then the sky is cloudy," we can use the logical implication (→) operator. In propositional logic, the statement "P → Q" is true unless P is true and Q is false. The truth table for the implication operator is as follows:

P | Q | P → Q
--------------
T | T |   T
T | F |   F
F | T |   T
F | F |   T

Since we don't have the actual truth values for P and Q, we cannot determine the specific truth value for the proposition "If it is raining today, then the sky is cloudy." However, we can represent it symbolically as "P → Q."
